service_territory.description: MISO operates in Illinois through two primary utility service territories. Ameren Illinois serves central and southern Illinois (Zone 4), while northern Illinois is primarily served by ComEd which operates in PJM territory, not MISO. Illinois is unique as the only fully competitive state in the MISO region.
service_territory.geographic_coverage: 43,700 square miles covering approximately three-quarters of Illinois, primarily central and southern regions
service_territory.notes: ComEd serves northern Illinois including Chicago, but operates in PJM territory, not MISO. Ameren Illinois covers the vast majority of MISO's Illinois footprint. Illinois is the only fully competitive state in MISO, while utilities in other MISO states remain vertically integrated.

programs.description: Emergency demand response resource that reduces load during grid emergencies to prevent rolling blackouts. LMRs are part of MISO's resource adequacy framework and are obligated to respond during emergency events. LMRs receive capacity payments through MISO's Planning Resource Auction and must respond when MISO declares emergency conditions.

eligibility.aggregation_level: Load Zone CPNode level only - resources can be aggregated together to meet the 100 kW minimum
requirements: Ability to reduce electricity consumption by at least 100 kW
Legal title and ability to control the resource
Must be capable of sustaining reduction for at least 4 consecutive hours
Must be able to respond at least 5 times during Planning Year when called upon
eligibility.illinois_specific_notes: Illinois is the only MISO state that allows third-party aggregators to participate, making it highly favorable for aggregated demand response participation. Except for Illinois, all other states in MISO opted out of DER participation and disallowed aggregators.

notification_and_response.deployment_trigger: Energy Emergency Alerts (EEA) and grid emergencies

capacity_credits.description: Capacity credits based on notification time requirements and sustained performance capability
capacity_credits.accreditation_basis: Peak demand periods: June-August, 2:00 PM - 6:00 PM

compensation.primary_payment: Zonal Resource Credits (ZRCs) from Planning Resource Auction
compensation.payment_basis: Capacity payment per MW-day for availability during planning year

recent_capacity_prices.notes: Prices hit Cost of New Entry (CONE) cap due to capacity shortage in MISO North
Dramatic price drop from previous year due to new capacity coming online
Flat pricing across most MISO zones except Zone 5 Missouri
22x increase in summer prices; first year using Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC)

compensation.energy_market_participation: Not allowed for LMRs - emergency response only, no energy market bidding
compensation.must_offer_description: LMRs must make capacity available to Day-Ahead market or Resource Adequacy Construct mechanisms if registered for capacity

performance_requirements.testing_threshold: Demonstrate at least 50% of registered capability
testing_methods: Real power test initiated by MISO
Actual deployment during MISO emergency event counts as test
performance_requirements.baseline_verification: Third-party auditor verification required if no state/retail regulatory accreditation
baseline_methodologies: Firm Service Level (FSL) - predetermined load reduction target
Meter Before/Meter After - comparison of consumption before and during event
Baseline Type-I - historical interval meter data with weather/calendar adjustments
performance_requirements.meter_data_requirements: Hourly meter data for 15 days before and 15 days after event, submitted within 53 calendar days
performance_requirements.performance_measurement: Load reduction measured against established baseline using approved methodology

penalties.non_performance_penalty: Value of Load (VOLL) multiplied by MW shortfall
penalties.penalty_notes: FERC approved nearly 3x increase in VOLL from $3,500 to $10,000/MWh, significantly increasing non-performance penalties

steps: Register as Market Participant with MISO (60-90 day process)
Obtain D-U-N-S Number and OATI webRegistry approval
Provide documentation of load reduction capabilities
Obtain Load Serving Entity (LSE) and Load Balancing Area (LBA) confirmation
Obtain RERRA (Regional Entities for Resource Reliability Assessment) approval
Potential third-party auditor verification of baseline
Submit to Planning Resource Auction or Fixed Resource Adequacy Plan (FRAP)
registration_process.registration_manual: BPM-001 Market Registration, BPM-026 Demand Response Business Practices
registration_process.use_elemental_pricing_nodes: Required for PY 2025-2026 auction registration onwards
registration_process.aggregator_requirements: Must register as Aggregator of Retail Customers (ARC) and submit end-use customer contracts (2024 reform)

reform_timeline.milestone: FERC Tariff filing for LMR accreditation reforms
FERC filing to eliminate dual LMR/EDR registration
Last year for dual LMR/EDR registration
Full implementation of LMR Type I/II reforms with new notification times

program_changes.eliminating_dual_registration: LMRs can no longer be registered as Emergency Demand Response (EDR) starting PY 2026-2027

new_lmr_types.deployment_trigger: Energy Emergency Alerts and Warnings leading up to emergency event

program_changes.testing_reforms: All new LMRs Type I will undergo initial testing by MISO; LMR Type II deployment during emergency counts as test; addressing concerns about self-testing and 50% testing thresholds

battery_suitability.overall_suitability: HIGH - LMRs are well-suited for battery energy storage systems
suitability_factors: Behind-the-meter batteries explicitly eligible as LMR-BTMG resources
100 kW minimum allows participation of utility-scale and large C&I batteries
4-hour discharge duration aligns with typical battery storage systems
Limited annual dispatch (0-3 events typical, up to 16 maximum) preserves battery cycles
High capacity payments ($666.50/MW-day summer 2025) provide strong revenue stream
No energy market bidding reduces operational complexity for LMR batteries
considerations: High non-performance penalties ($10,000/MWh VOLL) require reliable performance
6-hour or 30-minute notification depending on LMR Type (effective 2028)
Cannot participate in energy markets as LMR (would need separate DRR registration)

programs.program_type: Energy and Ancillary Services Market Participation
programs.market_type: Wholesale energy and operating reserves markets
programs.description: Economic demand response that participates in MISO's Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets, as well as ancillary services markets. DRRs provide grid flexibility during normal operations and are dispatched based on economic offers. Unlike LMRs which are emergency-only, DRRs can earn revenue through regular energy market participation.

drr_types.description: Customer programs like industrial interruptible load, controlled appliance programs that provide energy or reserves through physical load interruption
Behind-the-meter generators or highly controllable load processes that can receive electronic dispatch instructions and follow 5-minute setpoints
drr_types.response_time_reserves: 10-15 minutes for spinning reserves, continuous for regulating reserves
drr_types.control_requirements: Must receive MISO operator instructions electronically and follow 5-minute dispatch setpoints

eligibility.minimum_capacity_drr: Not specified for individual DRR registration
eligibility.minimum_for_aggregator: 1 MW+ enrolled demand to register with demand response aggregator
eligibility.minimum_capacity_general: 1 MW minimum for participation in MISO markets
requirements: Ability to reduce electricity consumption or increase behind-the-meter generation
Type II must follow 5-minute dispatch instructions electronically
eligibility.illinois_specific_notes: Illinois allows third-party aggregators, unlike most other MISO states. This enables smaller resources to aggregate to meet minimum capacity requirements.

energy_market_participation.day_ahead_market: Can submit energy offers; must offer if cleared Planning Resource Auction
energy_market_participation.payment_structure: Locational Marginal Price (LMP) if deployment is economically beneficial

net_benefits_price_threshold.description: DRR only paid if LMP exceeds NBPT - ensures grid benefits from dispatching DR
net_benefits_price_threshold.nbpt_determination: Established monthly by MISO and released in advance
net_benefits_price_threshold.nbpt_purpose: Ensures benefits from reduced LMP exceed cost of dispatching DRR
net_benefits_price_threshold.recent_proposal: MISO proposing offer floor at NBPT level to prevent gaming and fraud

energy_market_participation.co_optimization: Energy and ancillary services markets are co-optimized in market clearing

compensation.capacity_market: Optional - DRR may register as Capacity Resource OR LMR, but not both simultaneously
compensation.energy_payment: LMP for demand reduction when LMP > NBPT
compensation.ancillary_services_payment: Market clearing price for specific reserve product
compensation.payment_condition: Only paid if deployment found beneficial to grid (LMP > NBPT for energy)

spinning_reserves.eligible_resources: DRR Type I and Type II

supplemental_reserves.eligible_resources: DRR Type I and Type II

ramp_capability.description: Ability to increase/decrease output to follow load ramps

steps: Register as Market Participant with MISO (60-90 day process)
Submit Certification of Relationships for DRRs
Potential Aggregator of Retail Customers (ARC) Certificate
For Type II: Install telemetry and control systems meeting MISO requirements
Obtain LSE/LBA confirmation and RERRA approval
registration_process.registration_manual: BPM-001 Market Registration, BPM-026 Demand Response Business Practices

performance_requirements.dispatch_compliance: Must respond to MISO Dispatch, Setpoint, or Scheduling Instructions
performance_requirements.baseline_calculation: Load reduction measured from baseline load level using approved methodology
performance_requirements.tariff_violation: Failure to respond constitutes Tariff violation

program_status.note: Low participation compared to LMR programs (600 MW DRR vs 11,824 MW LMR in MISO)

battery_suitability.overall_suitability: VERY HIGH - DRR Type II is ideal for battery energy storage systems
suitability_factors: DRR Type II explicitly designed for behind-the-meter generators and controllable resources
Batteries can provide continuous variable output required for Type II
Can participate in all ancillary services markets (regulating, spinning, supplemental, ramp)
Energy market participation provides multiple revenue streams
Fast response capabilities of batteries match telemetry/5-minute dispatch requirements
considerations: Requires telemetry installation and real-time communication with MISO
Must be capable of receiving and executing electronic dispatch instructions
Net Benefits Price Threshold (NBPT $28-52/MWh) limits energy market revenue in low-price conditions
Cannot be registered as both LMR and DRR simultaneously
Lower total market participation (only 79 MW Type II across MISO) suggests complexity or barriers
battery_suitability.recommended_battery_configuration: Front-of-meter or sophisticated behind-the-meter systems with telemetry and automated dispatch capabilities
battery_suitability.recommended_battery_size: 1 MW+ for direct participation, smaller systems can aggregate
battery_suitability.ideal_use_case: Batteries seeking maximum revenue through energy arbitrage and ancillary services stacking

sources: https://cdn.misoenergy.org/Fact Sheet - MISO Market Participation Overview632546.pdf

programs.program_name: Emergency Demand Response (EDR) - Being Phased Out
programs.description: Emergency demand response resources that can reduce load or operate backup generation during grid emergencies. This program is being eliminated with dual LMR/EDR registration ending after PY 2025-2026. MISO has never called upon EDRs in its history.

phase_out_timeline.reason: Consolidating to two programs (DRR and LMR) for simplification; EDR never dispatched in MISO history

current_requirements.capability: Reduce load or operate backup generation during emergencies
current_requirements.historical_dispatch: MISO has never called upon EDRs

transition_plan.description: Resources currently registered as both LMR and EDR must choose one program after PY 2025-2026

battery_suitability.recommendation: Battery operators should register as LMR for capacity revenue or DRR Type II for energy and ancillary services revenue

planning_resource_auction.description: Annual capacity auction for resource adequacy ensuring sufficient resources to meet demand plus reserves
planning_resource_auction.recent_trends: Significant price increases due to declining reserve margins, generator retirements, and implementation of Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC)

zone_4_price_history.driver: Reserve margin decline to 2.6 GW, RBDC implementation

planning_resource_auction.rbdc_implementation: First used in 2025-2026 auction; introduces reliability-focused pricing that reflects capacity value as system approaches adequacy targets

energy_markets.day_ahead_market: Forward energy market cleared day before delivery
energy_markets.real_time_market: Spot energy market for actual delivery, 5-minute dispatch intervals
energy_markets.co_optimization: Energy and ancillary services co-optimized in market clearing to maximize social welfare
energy_markets.pricing: Locational Marginal Pricing (LMP) based on supply/demand and transmission constraints

transmission_zones.zone_4_description: Central and southern Illinois, includes Ameren Illinois service territory
transmission_zones.zone_4_characteristics: Experienced high volatility in capacity prices; structural challenges led to ICC investigation of MISO membership benefits
transmission_zones.lrz_purpose: Address congestion limiting resource deliverability and define capacity benefits for local reliability

aggregation_and_third_party.aggregator_definition: Market Participant sponsoring DRRs, LMRs, and/or EDRs provided by end-use customers that the ARC does not serve at retail
aggregation_rules: LMRs may only be aggregated up to Load Zone CPNode level
Individual resources as small as 100 kW can be aggregated together
End use customer account can only be registered by one Market Participant
Requires LSE and LBA confirmation for registration changes
aggregation_and_third_party.illinois_advantage: Illinois is the only MISO state that allows third-party aggregators, unlike all other MISO states which opted out of DER aggregation
aggregation_and_third_party.2024_reforms: ARCs must now submit signature pages of contracts with end-use customers to prevent fraud

curtailment_service_providers.illinois_presence: Serves industrial, healthcare, government, education and commercial sectors with Ameren Illinois and municipal/cooperative members
curtailment_service_providers.notes: Expanded footprint in MISO Illinois and Michigan

curtailment_service_providers.illinois_presence: Exclusive partnership with Ameren Illinois since 2015
curtailment_service_providers.notes: Claims better and more consistent pricing than MISO LMR through Ameren partnership

aggregation_and_third_party.minimum_capacity_via_aggregator: 1 MW+ enrolled demand for aggregator registration

implementation_milestones.milestone: DEAR Energy & Ancillary Services Market Participation

ferc_order_2222_implementation.ferc_compliance_issues: FERC determined MISO is not compliant with locational requirements of Order 2222; MISO has not demonstrated proposed requirements are as geographically broad as technically feasible
ferc_order_2222_implementation.illinois_context: Illinois distributed energy resources can participate through existing DRR programs while awaiting full Order 2222 implementation
ferc_order_2222_implementation.stakeholder_concerns: State regulators and stakeholders criticizing slow implementation timeline; MISO unlikely to accelerate without FERC direction

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Performance-based accreditation, shortened notification times (6 hours Type I, 30 minutes Type II), standardized testing by MISO
drivers: Increased grid uncertainty from renewable integration
Concerns about self-testing abuse and 50% testing threshold

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Simplification to two DR programs: DRR and LMR
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Resources must choose either capacity-focused (LMR) or energy-focused (DRR) participation; EDR never dispatched in MISO history

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Prohibit DRR offers below Net Benefits Price Threshold to prevent gaming
major_reforms_2024_2025.purpose: Address market fraud and gaming concerns; ensure DRR deployment provides net benefits to grid

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Non-performance penalties increased from 3×LMP to VOLL ($10,000/MWh)
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Significantly higher financial consequences for non-performance; nearly 3x increase from $3,500 to $10,000/MWh

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Aggregators must submit signature pages of end-use customer contracts
major_reforms_2024_2025.purpose: Prevent fraud and ensure legitimate demand response registrations

drivers: Load growth from data centers and electrification
Boom-bust price cycles due to vertical demand curve
capacity_market_trends.rbdc_impact: First year of Reliability-Based Demand Curve (2025-2026) produced record summer prices; provides more stability and reliability-focused pricing signals

illinois_specific_considerations.regulatory_environment: Only fully competitive state in MISO region; vertically integrated utilities in other MISO states
illinois_specific_considerations.aggregator_advantage: Illinois is the ONLY MISO state allowing third-party aggregators, providing unique opportunity for distributed energy resources
illinois_specific_considerations.zone_4_challenges: Experienced extreme capacity price volatility; ICC investigated whether MISO membership benefits Illinois customers
illinois_specific_considerations.ameren_service_territory: 43,700 square miles, 1.2 million electric customers, 1,200+ communities in central and southern Illinois
illinois_specific_considerations.competitive_landscape: Illinois customers can participate through competitive retail suppliers and demand response aggregators unlike other MISO states
illinois_specific_considerations.state_legislation: Illinois passed energy legislation envisioning dynamic relationship with customers installing distributed energy devices, ahead of FERC Order 2222 implementation
illinois_specific_considerations.miso_vs_pjm: Northern Illinois (ComEd territory) operates in PJM, not MISO; creates potential arbitrage and market comparison opportunities

advantages: Lower complexity - no telemetry required for LMR
Limited annual dispatches preserve battery cycles

medium_systems_1mw_to_5mw.primary_program: LMR for capacity + separate DRR Type II for energy/ancillary services (cannot do both simultaneously)
medium_systems_1mw_to_5mw.alternative_program: DRR Type II only for energy arbitrage and ancillary services stacking
medium_systems_1mw_to_5mw.revenue_streams: Capacity payments ($666.50/MW-day summer) OR energy + ancillary services
advantages: High capacity prices in current market
Can optimize between LMR and DRR strategies based on market conditions

large_systems_5mw_plus.primary_program: DRR Type II for maximum revenue optimization
large_systems_5mw_plus.secondary_consideration: LMR if capacity revenues exceed energy arbitrage + ancillary services
large_systems_5mw_plus.revenue_streams: Energy arbitrage, regulating reserves, spinning reserves, supplemental reserves, ramp capability, capacity (optional)
advantages: Fast-response capabilities valued in all ancillary services markets
Sufficient scale to justify telemetry and market operations infrastructure
Can provide regulating reserves (DRR Type II only)

behind_the_meter_considerations.lmr_btmg: Behind-the-meter batteries can participate as LMR-BTMG (Behind-the-Meter Generation)
behind_the_meter_considerations.drr_type_ii: BTM batteries with discharge to grid capability can participate as DRR Type II if telemetry installed
behind_the_meter_considerations.non_injecting_btm: Non-injecting BTM storage may continue to participate as demand response
behind_the_meter_considerations.meter_requirements: Front-of-meter batteries registering as wholesale resources have different metering standards than demand response

key_success_factors: Illinois aggregator-friendly regulation is unique competitive advantage in MISO
High capacity prices ($666.50/MW-day summer 2025) make LMR very attractive
DRR Type II offers most flexibility but requires telemetry investment
Cannot be both LMR and DRR simultaneously - must choose strategy
High non-performance penalties ($10,000/MWh) require reliable systems
4-hour duration requirement aligns with standard battery configurations

revenue_potential_example.scenario: 1 MW / 4 MWh battery in Illinois Zone 4, LMR participation

capacity_revenue_annual.notes: Based on PY 2025-2026 auction clearing prices

revenue_potential_example.dispatch_risk: 0-3 typical dispatches per year, up to 16 maximum, preserves battery cycles
revenue_potential_example.penalty_risk: Must perform when called or face $10,000/MWh × shortfall penalty
revenue_potential_example.net_assessment: Strong revenue potential with limited cycle degradation

data_quality_notes.no_invented_data: All data sourced from publicly available MISO documents, regulatory filings, FERC orders, and industry analysis
data_quality_notes.source_attribution: All key facts include source URLs
data_verification_approach: Cross-referenced multiple independent sources for all numerical values
Used official MISO publications and FERC documents as primary sources
Confirmed Illinois-specific information through ICC and utility sources
Validated capacity auction prices from multiple industry reports

Monthly NBPT values for 2024 - range of $28-52/MWh confirmed but month-by-month breakdown not published in accessible sources
Illinois-specific MW capacity of LMR/DRR programs - only MISO-wide totals available in public documents

Limited only by lack of Illinois-specific program participation data and detailed county-level information. All capacity prices, program rules, and penalty structures verified through multiple authoritative sources.

integration_metadata.optimizer_notes: Battery optimization systems can integrate MISO DR programs. Key decision: LMR (capacity-focused, limited dispatch) vs DRR Type II (energy arbitrage + ancillary services). Cannot do both simultaneously.
integration_metadata.api_notes: MISO requires Market Participant registration and proprietary market systems for automated dispatch. DRR Type II requires telemetry and electronic dispatch capability. No public API for DR participation.
integration_metadata.notes: Illinois offers unique advantages for battery storage DR participation: (1) Only MISO state allowing aggregators, (2) High capacity prices in recent auctions, (3) Multiple program pathways. Key trade-off: capacity revenue certainty (LMR) vs. energy market optimization (DRR Type II).
